headline: AGCS NA is broken
pros: Some employee benefits, however, they are changing and becoming less attractive. Flat structure and the possibility of RIFs only when there is change of strategy. The current policy is focused in promoting women into management roles. The broken processes and procedures give top talent an opportunity to provide value to the organization but wait and read the cons below first before making a judgement call.
cons: Culture is political and because of a flat org structure promotions are also political. The best person doesn’t necessarily get the promotion and teams are lead by status quo and mediocre individuals. Middle management, such as “Head” roles, are occupied by individuals who lack integrity, ability, and people management skills. They drive their top talent out. Annual assessments follow the same approach and don’t necessarily reflect reality, one sided and the house is not held responsible. A lot of finger pointing and nonsense that I witnessed across the different departments. Where is HR, some ask, no where (paper pushers). On top of this horrible culture then you have the broken processes and procedures that drive staff to the brim of insanity. Failures since 2011 with the global implementation of an outdated middle office system that no one was happy with. This place is not good for morale and management from the top to the bogus middle management is a big contributor to it all. Just look at their large list of open roles, those roles are not new but vacated by people who had enough.

headline: North American Branch is Dying
pros: paycheck, pto, 401k, dont really have to do much because they are desperate

The North American branch has been run into the ground with bad management for years. People in all areas of the North America are quitting in droves. CEO is a clueless clown who has no idea what his employees want. CFO is a status quo bozo. IT is a joke. Systems don't work. Last one out turn off the lights. As Hawk Harrelson used to say....THIS GAME IS OVA!!!

headline: Don't do it if you have other options
pros: The company has good benefits and modern offices.
cons:
For a giant name like Allianz, the US side is just simply embarrassing. Company is completely disorganized and chaotic. Everyone just does their own thing, their own way, like in the wild west. Claims has zero structure and segmentation. You will handle everything from the 15K PD claim to NY Labor Law to an amputation to construction defect, regardless or your experience or training or what your job description actually was when you interviewed. 
Management is very sissified and ineffectual. I have seen more spine in jellyfish. IT is a disaster with no accountability. HR is downright rude and unhelpful. Communication to the rank and file is non existent. Favoritism is very much present and they don't even try to hide it. They have no diversity and they do not hire from the outside unless it's for a lower level job. Expect to never get promoted unless you have been working there for decades and are part of the clique. Management is constantly "reviewing" and "discussing" but there is zero action taken. They made a huge deal about the new and improved Allianz but kept the exact same management and practices, ultimately changing nothing. Motto is "this is how we've always done it". Culture is awful. It is not surprising there is currently a mass exodus. They have a long way to go.

headline: Good Company
pros:
I have been working for 2 years at Allianz Technology, Trivandrum. Pros are

- Awesome work life balance.
- Lots of other activities apart from your regular work. 
- Going to be hybrid work model post covid. Need to go to office only 10 days per month.
- Most seniors, colleagues are very supporting
- Good learnings. Classroom trainings, Online training. They have YPWP (you pass we pay) and you can take any external certifications and company pacys back once you clear
- PGDBA higher study option. Distant learning course and tied up with symbiosis. 
- Alternative years you will get free Allianz shares with 3 year locking. You can also by in 25% discount to market rate.
- You will find most of the people are here with 5 year, 10 years experience. Good company to settle down. 
- If you are looking for a peaceful, stress free company then this is for you. You will be working for your parent company so clients are very supporting.
cons:
- Below market standard pay. 
- Hike in single digits. Last year 7%.
- Pathetic office laptop. Good for nothing.

headline: An ok but disjointed working experience
pros:
+For a starting employee, Allianz pays a decently for this role. 
+401K and Health Benefits
+The training is broken into 3 parts, and seems simple enough, until you actually get on the floor
cons:
- Once you do get on the floor, You notice that the majority of questions you have were covered nowhere in training. 
- Does not help at all that many of training materials you use, as well as the documentation you interface with are quite outdated. Some just plain obsolete
- Lack of support for Card Holders: Seems like day after day card holders are transferred to us from various directions for things we cannot assist them with, and it's definitely getting to a point where they routinely end up on my line already pre-frustrated from numerous calls and long hold times.

headline: Honest review about the organisation.
pros: If you are working wholeheartedly they will not fire you and salary will be on time

The management side is at worst they didn't care about their employes at all they just want you to work like bonded labour.
Once you enter the organisation your social life will be 0 ,this organisation management ruins you mental health .
Even when you are sick in case of viral fever they ask to you either login or provide medical nd even if you have paid leave they will mark you as absent. Its totally management centric organisation. Will not recommend anyone.

headline: Allianz Consulting Asia :  ruined by leadership
pros:
- Big name company, looks good on CV
- Good for young graduates to get first exposure to insurance , then progressively gets worse
- Can create some opportunities to transfer to other departments or countries, though much lesser nowadays
cons:
- Biggest con is leadership. No vision, no experience of running a consulting team. 
- Management has an easy trigger on blaming consultants rather than accepting constructive criticism
- Very poorly adapted to wfh in Covid times. No notion of private life, no lunch breaks, calls in the middle of the night etc..
- Talents running away, ~50% yearly turnover for last two years. Oldest standing team members are all gone, meaning learning experiences for younger colleagues will be of lesser quality 
- Salary and career opportunities are below par past senior consultant stage. Gerontocracy is strong in the Singapore office

headline: It is what it is
pros:
People. Allianz is full to the brim with the most committed, passionate and caring people who will go above and beyond all the time for a great outcome.
Some of the leaders that genuinely care and show compassion, support and drive their teams to succeed are some of the best leaders around. An excellent breeding ground for talent. 
Genuine approach to diversity and inclusion.
cons:
The last few years Allianz has lost what made them great through regulation reform, bad strategy, unclear plans and a “make it happen” approach to everything at once even though it’s contradictory. The pacesetters in senior positions have burnt everyone out with unclear direction, multiple revisions changes and pressure and a just get it done fear led leadership style.
Remuneration is completely unbalanced as is way too low in some areas and way too high in others.

headline: Wrong Hiring, no accountability
pros: Allianz is a great company to work. Quite beneficiary for employees regarding their online learning, other functions like house competitions n activities.
cons:
If I start listing cons one will forget the positive side ( just from team perspective) Allianz itself is great. 

CEO of Allianz I am sure is not aware about these parasites working as managers in the org. 

First of all they came with a different requirement to hire me. When I started working they said the requirements has changed and the work that was handed over to me was just a copy paste work. As a Content management team I was not having any authority to comment over the database they created. I guess such pathetic kind of work management would never be done in any MNC. The higher / upper management is way too pathetic n dramatic. Only space for Malayalees. Even the manager try to sheild the employees from Kerala only. Lead with Servicedesk field is leading over Content management. And the policy for changing team is painful. They ask to wait 18 months after joining which is way too long. The entire team politics leads to mental pressure n harassment resulting resignation.

headline: Management needs to trust lower level employees
pros:
work life balance
good pay
stable job
support during pandemic
cons: Humble request to management - there were talks of flexible/hybrid working model during pandemic last year. But there is no news about that. It was also not a good feeling when management asked those willing can come to office ( though no one was forced). After many years I was able to be with my family for a long time. Office was about 400/500 km away from my home. so even travelling on weekends and going back on monday was a pain. Though there is some 30days of wfh , if an employee was availing it was being looked down. Very humble request to trust us. there was no dip in productivity during wfh. Though I am in my home town , I am still paying the rent because there has been no official date communicated yet. At least give a date till 2022 like many companies did.Allianz always took bold and industry first moves. Humble request to management to give a date attest till 2022 and after that please introduce hybrid working model where in an employee can work from office for 2/3 days and remaining days from home. Please don't leave this policy with approval of LM/line manager as if this is an option then they might not show that flexibility to give approvals. Please make it mandatory. With folded hands , It's a humble request .

headline: At risk of becoming the titanic
pros:
Strong technical development on underwriting, policy wordings, trades, industries and other insurance concepts. I have worked at multiple different insurance organisations and this is some of the best training I have received.
You will be given a high degree of responsibility, dealing with a range of broker accounts, products and tasks from day one. If you want to become an underwriter this is a good place to start. 
Pre-covid, there was regular social activities both internally and externally with the wider insurance market. I am sure this will eventually come back. 
Staff are friendly and easy to work with. 
The board and senior management provide regular updates on company strategy via meetings and email. 
Discounts on gym membership, retail and a range of other things. 
The company supports national charities and you will be able to participate in thier fund raising activities and events.
The business is flexible on your life circumstances and you can work from home.
cons:
From the beginning of the covid pandemic, the organisation and running of the business has appeared to take a turn. The company has been under resourced for so long, morale has taken a huge dip and any staff that are left are burnt out. 
Staff turnover is high meaning as an underwriter, you will be spending a portion of your time training and retraining new employees. The company does not really look after thier existing staff in the way of reward and recognition, meaning the most experienced underwriters move on after a few years leaving the juniors to run the shop. This is counterproductive to moral because the juniors come in with little insurance experience and so this hurts both the existing staff who have to keep picking up the pieces and the new staff who are overwhelmed by the basics. Graduates come into the business on more money than non graduates for the same role which is also demotivating to some of the junior to mid level underwriters.
Expect to work very hard in return for very little pay and annual bonus. Allianz is such a large company you will be viewed as another number at the end of the day. 
Underwriters are left to manage thier own weeks, but when you raise issues with management they come up with excuses and don't do anything about it. I think they mean well but there's definitely some communication issues between teams.
Moving to full online trading and management has wrecked the core fabric of the team. 
Underwriting strategy is out of step with the rest of the market and can be challenging to execute long-term.
Pay does not increase with experience. 
Managers seem to care more about numbers and how it reflects on them, rather than the sustained impact on thier staff.

headline: An organisation going through major change (for the better)
pros:
It is quite a traditional company which the new CEO is updating. The tech in place now is old but billions of dollars are being spent to update it. Everything is changing to make it an up-to-date and attractive employer.

They are great with their D&I stuff. I worked in a major insurance brokerage previously and they said a lot of words but did not walk the talk. In Allianz, they really believe and act it.
cons:
Dealing with out of date tech now! Aaargh!

It is a big organisation, sometimes people can get lost or struggle to climb up the promotional ladder. That is reflective of the company size though rather than Allianz.

headline: Working Student: very frustrating experience
pros:
Work/life balance
Good company name (might look good on resume)
Good canteen
cons:
- Disgusting office (greasy keyboard and mouse)
- lack of professionalism (no code reviews, no version control, data input files get lost, and no-one cares... [it is acknowledged that the status quo is problematic, but no-one has the guts to do something about it])
- Working students are treated like ghosts (never got formally introduced to the line manager, spoke to him briefly after one year; did many analyses and crafted many emails to him in that year with my name underneath, but never was involved in any oral discussions). Interns have it slightly better...
- Pay is low ("We pay in experience, not in money"... if only...)
- Colleagues know their business stuff well, but usually understanding is not too deep. Regarding statistical methodology and programming skills, I have experienced nothing but amateurism.
- Slogan says "Home of those who dare". If you try this in reality, you will not be rewarded. Allianz is a very rigid dinosaur, ideas and out-of-the-box thinking are not welcome. What matters is only "what story we tell", "how we sell this point" (note that this is about group risk, not a marketing department). There is oftentimes time pressure and deadlines, sometimes with short notice. But quality or sound methodology does not matter, is not expected and is usually not appreciated.

headline: Failry sub-optimal organisation and  staffing - NOT RECOMMENDED
pros:
+ Backing from the Allianz Board of Directors, with many investing decisions supported by people such as Oliver Baete (AZ CEO) or Ivan de la Sota (Chief Business Transformation Officer)
+ Central offices on the AZ HQ block, with direct access to the AZ canteen as well as many nice restaurants in the Maxvorstadt neighborhood
+ Back-office functions (Finance, Compliance) directly on-site and kindly helpful despite the pressure on them
+ Use of strategic consulting services of McKinsey & Company, given top AZ management being from McK and need for external intelligence; however, deep reluctance of AZX staff to cooperate with McK staff
cons:
- The calibre of employees is very low for an investing vehicle, and fallaciously stated on communications materials (e.g., website, pitchbooks)/over-exaggerated on AZX website/LinkedIn (e.g. the CFO pretends to have worked at investment bank "Robertson Stephens", whereas Google shows the latter as a wealth management firm
- No access to either the Allianz trade union or corporate advantages - the entity is standalone, so outside of the very advantageous Allianz Deutschland framework
- There is a pervasively toxic and conservative culture, whereby strong pressure from the CEO, ongoing fear climate throughout the teams and heavy-lifting to tame people taking initiatives instead of simply executing 
- Be careful upon joining: extremely high turnover, with almost half of staff having left during 2020 and probation periods used as a way to whimsically adjust FTE numbers (before financial reporting deadlines or to find cheaper staff on the market)
- Pay not in line with market standards, especially stated bonus potential not materialising year after year
- Very little upward mobility potential, with personnel either quickly moving to another Allianz organisational entity or leaving the AZ group to a real VC fund (e.g. Early Bird)
- Potential investee companies looking for funding are not treated with respect - they would not get a response or mocked when presenting to the AZX (almost all dealflow is inbound from AZ Board of Directors to please the latter)

headline: Supportive Management, Terrible Position
pros: My team leader was amazing and incredibly supportive, company has a big focus on mental health and wellbeing and the induction is 5 weeks long (the easiest part of the job because you're not on the phones) co-workers really supportive as well.
cons: PLEASE DO NOT take this position if you suffer from anxiety or any mental health issues. The job is incredibly draining and customers will be rude to you every day and wear you down very quickly. This position consists of grumpy/helpless people calling you all day trying to get a cheaper price on their insurance only for you to have to tell them "sorry but that's just how insurance works" not a good job for anyone who actually enjoys good customer service and looking after people.

headline: Great company, albeit a little unfair
pros:
The company ethos and what it stands for is something to be proud of. We have come very far in a short space of time. 
You will find a huge amount of support, especially from our head office and committees within the branch. 
They are very generous with expenses and making sure everyone is looked after.
cons:
A major con is fairness. You may find (as i do) that you have ample more experience than other colleagues who are on higher wages simply because they had a 'little' bit of prior experience. But when a new joiner starts 2k above you after you have been for the company for 2 years, simply because of a summer internship... you have to question where the fairness is. Or the graduate scheme, why are they on so much more than myself, despite needing a degree for my role anyway. 
We've had a lot of young people leave our branch simply because of the pay. It is not quick enough and unfair.

headline: good benefits because nothing else is
pros:
good benefits package. 
Most people are nice.
cons:
poor culture - favoritism, cronyism,  ZERO diversity. No genuine feedback requested or cared for. People lack empowerment. No one speaks up. Mostly drones work here. Layoffs due to years of mismanagement, lack of profit, and refusal to see and adapt to what’s coming.
IT - awful. tickets stay open for weeks, have to use your cellphone for day to day business because company phone is not functional. ZERO sense of urgency to resolve anything, no automation or digitization for basic processes, you will spend hours sitting idle because of your systems. Company is about 10 years behind everyone else in tech. 
Management - VERY poor. Top heavy. Stubborn. Old fashioned. They lack new ideas and innovation, same circle of people have ran the company for years but they expect change and profitability? Highly inefficient processes and policies. Some teams can never catch up but others at same level do nothing all day. no uniformity or standards. No accountability and leadership. Minimal communication with the rank and file.

headline: Very political, extremely unfair
pros: Work-life balance is good. Salaries are hard to grow but overall if you negotiate very hard you can get a fair compensation (nothing spectacular)
cons: It is a highly political company, where meritocracy which used to be one of the motto comes second. There is a plan to promote a certain amount of women over a defined period which is also embedded in the targets of the management, this means men are highly discriminated and promotions are given to friends of friends or for diversity reason. Many good people have left the organisation which leaves you with a "lemon market" as poor people are promoted and good people leave. I definitely do not recommend the company. This is also bad for women as promoting a woman just to have a quota gives the impression that none of them are actually promoted because they are good at what their doing. The environment is pretty toxic even if it looks very friendly on the surface.

headline: [Allianz Tech] Old, slow but steady company, with old habits, tech, tools, processes
pros:
- A very rich company, the job stability is higher than compared to being a government-worker in some real countries
- Good opportunity to travel and even change countries
- Flexible schedule, Intensive summer schedule and Fridays
- "Relaxed" job if you make it so
cons:
- The company is super political. No matter if you're in tech or not. Few people are actually honest with you. Do watch out the games in the back and in the front. 
- Most of the Senior IT Managers have absolutely no clue about IT and about how it works, speaking superficially from what they have heard in Conferences, but never have seen it applied or are able to understand the complexity behind it.
- Very, but very old tech stack and way of doing things
- There is a lot of Managers for everything, much more than actual workers.
- I've seen people being discriminated at work based on their gender and age, and saw indiscrete proposals from an 3rd age woman towards younger male employees. 
- Slow company to drive change in: basic things get stuck for months because of the bureaucracy of the company
- The externals come and go and because of this, there is no continuity or sense of quality in the things done.
- Climb the ladder culture ( they even have a presentation in HR about that). If you reach the top, you can't be relegated.

headline: Know what you're getting yourself into
pros: AGCS in the US has very good benefits, international presence with offices around the world, people in general are friendly.
cons: I was at AGCS for a little over 5 years, and it was largely a mess. Years of poor company performance with no pay raises and slashed bonuses, along with massive layoffs and offshoring of certain departments led to low morale and a general sense of apathy from employees. On our quarterly company-wide financial calls people would even be openly calling out executives in the Q&A about the state of the company. In addition to this, there is a huge CYA/political landscape to navigate at AGCS as well. I was encouraged to only communicate via email and not call people in order to have records of everything to cover myself and my department in the future since trust among groups is low. AGCS US has to report to the Germany headquarters, and very often what works for Germany doesn't work for the US and vise versa which just led to gridlock, meetings about meetings, failed multi-year projects with layoffs, and everybody's time being wasted in the end. AGCS is about as corporate and bloated as it gets. The IT and tech is way behind the times as well. This is a company that up until only 2 years ago was still using Lotus Notes as the primary email client.

headline: nightmare in the Allianz Re for young talent of STEM field
pros: flexible working time, good cantine and still many nice human people at least,  except for harsh team and horrible management in queen regime.
cons:
- over high expectation in spite of low payment and little support/help for on the job.   As the typical rule always goes, "teach yourself swimming in the cold water"

- position for student with part time contract was not respected . It's just about squeezing the cheap student employee for high output as an full-time employee but for low payment.

- student worker are more squeezed as cheap victim paying for the inefficient IT-systems and for the lack of team internal communication, because in the same team, superviser A wants you to left however superviser B wants you to right,  whatever you do, you would always be the bad performer in the eyes of them and the manager. the manager is always busy and refused to hear anything from the subordinates.

evaluation based on a real case in a team within catastrophe department on a technical position. So a warning especially for those talents of STEM field

headline: No appreciation
pros: PTO days, 401k, 3 years vested
cons:
Management does not care, HR does not care. You are told this is an entry level job but they have you do the exact same jobs as everyone with the title higher than yours. You ask your supervisor with a question they will simply tell you, "look at last month" or "you should know this is your account now". You get bombarded with work and not a simple thank you or not a simple "good job". During my time here (about a year and half) I saw 3 co-workers leave and one get fired for just not showing up, even then management didn't say anything until we complained, yet management continue with their same strategies and techniques. There is no room for growth and your managers do not want you to succeed. Senior Management does not get involved until they realize their bonus is in jeopardy. The place is a mess and nothing will change until they fix management. This was by far one of the worst and unprofessional places I have ever worked. To move up, you need to know people in different places. This place does not care how many hours you put into it or how hard you work. So much for a bonus too, no salary increase either.

To top it all off, once you leave, they realize how much work you were doing so they promote the position! Way to appreciate your employees!

headline: Allianz Pune. Honest Review!
pros: None i can recall of
cons:
You are lucky if you are reading this before joining or still in training period.
01.Worked full time as developer
02. There is no process here . When you join they will keep you waiting for all the necessary access you require,VD ,work environment setup etc for 2-3 months so that you don't realize how  bad this company is as soon as you join.Smart guys leave when their NP is still 1 month.
After 2-3 months starts the Mindless video conferences, countless meetings - for no reason at all, nothing purposeful is discussed or achieved - ever. 
03.Full on politics goes here.It does not matter how good your work is,but if you know how to do politics and know how to lick managers at right place this is the best place.But all managers already have their favorites so for new people no scope for that also.
04.All the major,good projects have closed and existing ones are about to close.I hope they don't shut down this center.But looking at the state of management and quality of work it is better to do so.
05.Technology wise there is nothing to learn.They have a very old product(based on Core JAVA only).So if you wanna ruin your career join here.This is true for BA,java an host developer.
06.The senior management is all  from Kerala office.So they keep all the good opportunities for themselves and allocate all the broom work to us.So it is literally like you are working for them.So join here if you have no self respect,then you will do good here.
07. All they want is to increase head count for billing purposes. So that they can milk whatever they can from their parent  Global office. 
08. For  Kerala guys this is like government job,some of them are here for past 10-12 years.They lick the cherry  of every project and then leave it for us.
09. No one wants to work here.They are here only because of this reason even  if they pay them less as per market standard.So the company is full of dumb people with full on attitude.They don't have the etiquette to work  or talk professionally.On the floor you can see the manager shouting at his team and team members fighting with each other doing blame game.Worst work culture you can find here.BA blames tester,tester blames developer and poor developer can only blame his stars.
10.There have been cases when manager gives special favors(onsite) etc  to someone in return of some special favors. My manager used to text me at night and this happened with other friends of mine too.
11.HR is the worst here.They do not know how to do their Job. They will never solve your problem.Never expect anything from them.

headline: Constant headaches - no direction, unorganized
pros: I liked a lot of the employees and some of the leaders
cons: If you like being ridiculed on emails ( if you are right or not) with directors and account managers by your manager this is the perfect job for you. Training is very minimal. I enjoyed then first leader - they brought back one from the Toronto office and she was a nightmare. We worked right by our supervisor and could hear her talking down to him and snap and snark at him in front of the team. He was so stressed out-  he left and went to another team.  Seems like she sold the director out as the director was let go and she was very vocal and proud about it, and boasted she did all her work for her and she knew nothing. The absolute worst manager I have ever worked for, will not make it anywhere else because she has zero people skills and treats employees like garbage. Account managers, some managers are hostile and talk down and use negative humiliating tones in their communications. There is no accountability or pride. Walking through the office all you will find is people on their phones or gossiping.  If you do the minimal and do not care about the customers and cause drama you will fit in with this culture. The pay is terrible. very low and you cannot support a family on the salaries. They just let a whole bunch of people go to save money but they really should have looked at the leaders and started training better people. They advance people to different departments that has zero clue on how the departments are run causing shortages of work,  and angry customers. The mail room also loses confidential documents all the time.  I am very happy to not have that toxicity and the stress of working for a hostile manager in a toxic environment fueled with fear, intimidation and negativity,  have not looked back.

headline: CSR / Travel Sales Associate Experience
pros: 1. The building that the headquarters in Richmond is located in is very nice.
cons:
1. No matter what they tell you, it's an inbound call center.  You are expected to be available on the phones from the literal second (that's recorded) you log on, to the literal second (also recorded) you log off. You are given two 10 minute breaks, and a choice between a 30 minute or 60 minute lunch. If you choose the latter, your day is extended to accommodate the lost time on the phone. 
2. If you somehow end up in this situation with a degree, you will be reporting to an immediate supervisor whose highest tier of education is high school. This individual is responsible for pulling calls you took, supposedly at random, and critiquing them. If you fail an absurd metric, such as forgetting to provide a canned sequence of information at the end of a call, you will fail. Fail a call and you will forfeit any possibility of seeing a monthly bonus. 
3. Monthly bonuses: During my time in this position, my team generated premiums in excess of one million dollars every month for six months straight. If you failed a call, you would not realize any bonus for your contributions.  Fear not, for you WILL receive a rubber bracelet similar to the LIVE STRONG bracelets that instead reads "Million Dollar Club."  In addition, you will receive a coupon for a cup of soup redeemable at the cafe downstairs in the lobby. 
4. Employee Appreciation Days: Other departments are invited and welcome to join outdoor cookouts and half days with a cold beer. It looked very pleasant actually. I would have enjoyed them had we not been required to remain on the phones to continue servicing calls instead.
5. Staff Development: Career development is probably something that is valued in other departments. However if you are one of the unfortunate souls that make up the claims, customer service, or sales departments - you're doomed. During my two years there, I knew of only one person able to break out of these departments in a vertical transition to something like Finance, Underwriting, or Marketing. 
6. Weekends & Holidays: If you are in this role, you will be working alternating weekends. I have heard that since I left, you actually are compensated better for the mandatory weekend rotations. That being said, you are also expected to work Holidays. Every time you work a holiday, you accrue points. If you have enough points by the time a major holiday rolls around, say Christmas, there is a lottery system in place that works like a draft. If you do not have enough holiday points, you're working Christmas. While I was there, I worked every major holiday including Easter, Thanksgiving, and Christmas.
7. Hourly Pay: As stated above, I'm aware that there has since been adjustments to the hourly rate of CSR and Sales. When I was there, the base pay for normal business schedule was $13 / hour. If you wanted to see the most pay, you had to be willing to work from 4:00PM until midnight for $15 / hour. 
8. PTO: You must accrue the PTO before you can actually use it. You may not take off the same day that someone else on your team has reserved. There must always be enough people on the phones to service calls. 
9. The calls: Be prepared to deal with the absolute worst that this planet has to offer in terms of humanity or lack-thereof. You are the front lines for servicing phone calls for disgruntled customers that were foolish enough to fall for the product this company sells in the first place. The majority of your calls will be to either refund people that mistakenly purchased the policy at the time of purchasing tickets, or sell the policy itself, or notify a customer that their claim is not covered by the policy. I unfortunately had to tell numerous cancer patients that their condition was considered pre-existing and likely would not be covered by the policy at the time that they filed. By the end of the day, it was more common that I received some sort of death wish from a cancer patient than not. I can't say that I blame them. 
10. Management: They are aware of all of this. They do not care. They will always have a pool of people to draw from that hold a high school diploma, or are under employed with a bachelor's degree.

headline: AMOS / Allianz Technology, Pune
pros: There are no pros with this company. I have wasted my entire period of 1 and half years waiting to get good opportunities in the company and finally resigned out of frustration. The entire hierarchy is broken and lower grade employees suffer because of this. I really regret wasting my time here and I am writing this review so that people who are applying in this company know the truth.  As freshers, you will be trained for 2-3 months on Java, BFSI domain and behavioral skills then you will be alloted to ABS projects which have no learning associated whatsoever. ABS is not recognized outside Allianz and you will struggle to find better technologies to work on. Onsite opportunities are awarded to bootlickers but it is just a lollipop to keep employees trapped in Allianz.
cons:
Entire management is flawed. 
As a fresh graduate you will be offered 2.4 LPA and after 6 months of probation your pay will be 2.75 LPA. The base package offered is very low as compared to other companies. 
The HR department is the worst. They are literally crazy mofos who are arrogant in tone.
Do join this company if you want to ruin your future. There are lot of better options if you search hard and work hard too.

headline: Analyst
pros: Vacation Days, 401k match, International Experience
cons: There is NO work-life balance. They will make you work weekends and week nights after work and they do not award you with extra vacation days. The employees there live to work, not work to live. The environment is toxic. Upper management does not keep their promises either. One day they say one thing, the next day it is the complete opposite. The software is a mess that the processes and work experience is not professional at all. There is very little to no room for growth. Once you are hired, expect to stay in the same position until you leave. Allianz is the prime example if you know someone, you will make your way up the ladder. However, if you enjoyed high school drama and gossip, Allianz is the place to be because everyone talks about everyone in a negative way. Lastly, HR is not there for you at all, they are only their for the company and its reputation.

headline: Good company but struggling  currently...
pros: Well respected insurance company with a history of more than 100 year. Good canteen and well established. Overall trying to be agile and moving into right direction.
cons:
Lacking vision and not adapting very well into the current situation although trying hard to be agile. Its product and offerings has almost not changed since last 10 yrs. Only recently it introduced KFZ insurance that was somewhat competitive. 

Biggest contra is 
a. Too much management and hiearchy  (CIO..> Head of  XX-->Abteilungs --> ReferatsLeiter.....)      who basically produces no productive work. and slows down decision process
b. Product is not competitive compared to competitors like HUK24. Not targeting right segment.
c. Trying to build IT Product itself through Allianz Technology costing millions if not billions.

headline: Baffling
pros: Salary, benefits, stock, some aspects of the work environment / facilities / perks
cons: Like being on a freight train in the fog headed nowhere. Weird contradictory work environment. Things look healthy and promising one day and completely toxic the next. Management and peers tend to throw one another under the bus. Some upper management very dynamic and inspired but it doesn't trickle down properly. Much of the corporate culture is a phony facade. Antiquated systems and processes that will never get fixed or improved.  Loud chaotic open environment workspaces. In my humble opinion it would be best of Germany almost completely absorbed or even dissolved most of the American operations here.

headline: Deluded "leadership", cancerous silo mindset.
pros:
Life is easy, no much pressure is put on anyone.

There are some departments where there is a lot of innovation done, unfortunately they're completely bounded and gagged by bureaucracy and ineffectual leadership.
If you can bypass the useless, demotivating, upper management somehow, a lot of potential is there to creat great things.

Employees are cordial between them.  

Three month intensive schedule at summer.
cons:
Technological stagnation, low salaries and no career prospects whatsoever beyond promotion to Peter's level of incompetence. Which explains much of how the current leadership has gotten to where it is.
Low employee morale has left the company with low quality, unmotivated professionals; most of the good ones leave in less than a year. 
Technological decisions are made by people who have no knowledge to make them, ignoring the very people they've hired to help them.  They are often catastrophic.

There is no collaboration between departments, a lot of hostility and passive-agressive relations. And those departments are led by clearly incompetent people that "promoted" to that position to earn more money, since it´s the only way to advance your career in Alliance. Thus lowering overall morale. Everything is linked in a vicious circle of impeding doom.
Time flexibility is a complete joke. They will lie to you in the interview, also on the benefits you will receive, that only manifest after being some years in the company. Something you do not want to do if you like your technical career to advance.

Employees are not valued. Focus on external recruitment, no employee retention. No knowledge retention.

In the age of technological giants like Amazon, Google or Microsoft, that extend their reach to every business, Allianz is doomed. So are all other classic traditional insurance businesses. But Allianz is going head-on the path of obsolescence and irrelevance.

If you ever get an offer and you consider it, try to milk all the money you can get, because you won't ever get an upgrade while you work there. Also, do not fall into the performance review extra-work. You won't be rewarded by your extra work: salary upgrades are given by political reasons, not meritocratic ones as they like to flaunt.

headline: A mixed bag...

cons: Very corporate, face has to fit, those with an opinion don't get very far. People have to step on others to get anywhere. As said above, no progression or development in our branch now that it's downsized massively. It's not about the people, it's about the profit.

headline: Stay as far away as possible
pros: None that I can think of.
cons: Very clicky. Full of rumors. Everyone is related somehow. Lack of respect. Management knows absolutely nothing and is only still in their position due to personal relationships with people. They have a serious HR issue and don’t recognize it. Crazy amount of turn over. Managers don’t protect their teams but are first ones to throw them under the bus for their own decisions. You will only excel if you make friends with the catty management otherwise there is absolutely no growth in IT, change management or projects related to operations. People are all extremely two faced so watch your back. If you know management or are/become personal friends with then you are free to make your own hours. If not, get ready to be micro managed.

headline: Worst company to work.. extreme Politics & No policies, No processes
pros:
Available Onsite opportunity for BA only. For Dev & tester, trivendrum will be your onsite..lolzz but it's true guys.
Only trivendrum people get onsite opportunity.
cons:
Manager driven company. In 1 project you will find maximum BA 's as compare to other team players. HR just play role of poppet of managers. No policies & processes set. Maximum time you have to come in weekend because of failed project planning. Manager doesn't understand technical thing & they give false commitments to their business partners due to this reason every team member has to suffer a lot. When BA goes to onsite, they have to give unrealistic estimation to client because of management pressure as they want project here. They switched off AC during lunch time, tea time & in weekend they don't switch on AC as well. Manager literally threatened to employee if they denied to come on weekend. In few teams they use to work in weekend & sit in the office 26-27 hr & it doesn't matter you are man or woman. You will get F&F in 5-6 months with incorrect amount & if try to chase them then u won't get success due to HR unavailability. HR changes frequently & u can't Catch them after reliving. Extremely high level politics with micro management people
Pathetic appraisal very low as compare to market  standard. You have to clear their ABS internal exams,  otherwise everything will be effected & manger tells u  clearly & threatened you. Appraisal % is very very low.
Manager ues to abuse people on the floor. Managers will denied clearly what they have committed you.

headline: good big company but team culture varies

cons: team culture varies as similar in other companies, so one's satisfaction can vary a lot

headline: Bullying and harassment openly tolerated
pros: Good holidays and other perks. The standard of staff is very low because only people who have no choice but to tolerate the toxic culture stay, so it's easy to stand out if you are competent. International company so opportunity to travel.
cons: Toxic culture of bullying and harassment which flows from the board all the way down to middle management. I've dealt with Allianz offices all over the world and top people in Munich down to staff in local branches and it's the same everywhere. Believe me, pretty much everyone who works for this company hates it. Those who stay do so because nobody else would hire them, so incompetence is rife. Very bureaucratic. A big focus on cost control at the moment driven by the CEO which means everyone is under pressure to work harder for stagnant pay and worse conditions. Terrible IT systems because everything is outsourced at the lowest possible cost or sent to development centers in India. People routinely promoted into senior positions with little experience or training in the field they'll be managing. This company is making money at the moment, but they are doing so by burning their assets to make short term gains. Group strategy is an open joke full of cliches like Customer Centricity and Digital by Default with no concrete strategy behind them. Accept a job with this company, work there for a year then tell me if I'm wrong.

headline: A company to settle the life
pros:
Nice infrastructure, employee friendly, occasional company events.
Good treatment for contract employees
Fairly good work life balance
A good company to work if you need a job which gives you less headache after reaching home.
Occasional on-site opportunities(mainly 3 months of deputation and this is only for full time employees)
cons:
No technical growth
Office politics thrive here
Legacy systems
Very less learning opportunities.
10 years behind the current industry in technology.
Some manager(!s- I got this experience with only one manager here) sees contract employees are there to work and work only.
(This is purely my experience. I had my parent company drawing more money than their other vendors because of the quality of the people they sent, however this manager wanted me to work to make the hell out of me and I even came to know that he is forcing the team leads to give us more tasks. What to do if I finish my task in one third time their full timers took :-p)

headline: Great Place to Work...but know when you overstay your welcome
pros:
Great Work Life Balance
Unbeatable 401K match
If you like to travel, you get to see different part of the world (and since most of the offices are in the business district, you would travel to metropolitan, urban setting)
You get to learn a lot
cons:
-Politics; German vs US approach, NY vs Chicago vs Munich vs [whatever office location], could be unending, tiring, and honestly petty
-We are big (although limited brand recognition in the US), however we are little bit of everything and it is difficult to make meaningful changes unless you are the top mgt or close to their circle (but see my point above)
-If you are not in the circle, good luck in getting their attention. Tried so many times to get their time to talk only to be rebuffed. Best example was when I made a special day trip to NY only to see (one of) my boss across the hall walking to washroom and I got a waived of recognition :-) 
-For a company this big, I am surprised at how limited the opportunity I can get the more I move up. At times, the message I got is rather conflicting: "You are too expensive", "You may not have the expertise", or "Development is your responsibility so you figure it out your own" or sometimes I got no response whatsoever. Keep in mind, I step up when my predecessor got let go, grew the team, integrated the team w/ Fireman's Fund, participated successfully in Navigator, DDI training for Executives, etc. It's astonishing how the accomplishments meant nothing or how much support not received when I wanted to learn more.

headline: Good only for Malayalees
pros: Good work - life balance.
cons:
01. I am a former contractor turned FTE, have been awarded multiple times, highest performer because of my work, but could not grow in terms of learning and position because I am not a malayalee and a bum licker.
02. The senior management is all Malayalees except for one guy in Pune. All they want is to increase head count for billing purposes. They talk just about anything in the townhalls, and people who come form MNCs laugh at them.
03. All team leads are 10+ years experienced, Pappu's of their Managers in line and secretly try to hide their frustration.
04. The Managers hate it when you apply your brain and logic, because its only their way of thinking that is right.
05. Mindless video conferences, countless meetings - for no reason at all, nothing purposeful is discussed or achieved - ever.
06. Onsite visits for no reason what so ever, just for fun. Make a stupid business case and fly; thats it - its that simple.
07. People hired laterally are hired for any random skill and later given training for the real job. The KT never stops, 4 year old people are still taking KTs.
08. Out of the 400- staff in Pune, almost 80% has changed in the last 2 years including all the HR staff itself and half of the Senior Management. It is rumoured that the HoDs are running their own companies on family names.
09. Lavish parties and outings in the name of team building.
10. People are working there because they are unable to find jobs elsewhere.

headline: Trivandrum office- Really pathetic, Politics at its maximum,No career growth
pros:
1. Cab Facility.
2. Work space facilities.
cons:
1.No career growth, need to compromise with career if you are joining
2.No change in the roles for number of years ( most of the employees are doing same work in niche or legacy technologies/systems for the last 6+ years.
3. Very less inside job opportunities to move into, but micro management at its best.
4 Politics at its Highest level. From a systems analyst or G5 band role you can see the cheap politics.Real politicians will fail here. The current management is ex-Bajaj Allianz management which runs this IT/ITES operations of this company.
5. Favoritism at its best, will get good opportunities (if any) only if you support cheap politics.
6. Wrong information's spreading fast from the top level.
7. Senior Management will speak about career growth , role change by creating backup etc in meetings, but when we speak to our manager, they will say if you are fed up you can look outside, here these are the situations.
8. Manager(s) are not shy to tell lie to employees regarding opportunities and role change. They look only on their performance targets on keeping headcounts under them so they will not release employees to any other projects.
9.If any opportunities available through Internal Job posting- most of the managers will not release the employee by saying un-acceptable relieving time (3-4 months) to the hiring manager OR the manager will agree with the hiring manager in the background that employee will not be released, but they will not stop you from applying to that job posting because it will be an escalation on him. End result is - no change will happen.
10.For freshers recruitment there are also trap called ' contract employees'. Company will call for recruitment for permanent employees,  but after selection they will say no headcount available at the moment, so you join as a contract employee through a well known consultancy under their payroll and later we will move to a good role. It has very less salary and experience certificate will be from consultancy then and follow leave policies by consultancy which is not at all good. The employee will notice these things once they are IN.
11. As this is a global insurance company and huge IT support is required, most of the IT work are doing by other big service companies (vendors). 
12. Another hidden trap- Some of those big service companies (above said vendors) has made this company in their non-hiring list, so employees from this company cannot move to those big service companies.
13. Recently they introduced 5 point appraisal system ( previously 3 ) and promotion system, so now very few percentage of employees will enter in the first 3 buckets which has average salary hike.
14. Senior Managers will get role change or promotion.
15. For cost cutting they stopped the toilet tissues, but after surveys they put it back.
15. Recently reduced the flexibility of  work-from home facilities.

Takes a ridiculous amount of time to achieve simple tasks.  Zero level of service to internal customers and contempt if they are lucky.  Arrogance at every level, no communication down from senior management, no communication within the team.  Poor quality work, no documentation, no real change control but plenty of ticking boxes.  An embarrassing IT shop but a great place if you are nearing retirement and want to be paid to surf the web all day.  Uninspiring middle management.  No direction or strategy.

headline: Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty Tries Very Hard, Lacks Some Skill
pros:
This operating entity of Allianz says it is attempting a major culture shift. Top leadership wants to focus on customer centricity, innovation & technical competence, diversity and employee well being. 
 401k is generous, and vested after 3 years. Vacation time is generous. Relocation to global positions is encouraged.
cons: Competence of execution is significantly lacking in technology and UW areas. Fear rules; longterm employees have survived by not asking clarifying questions. Leadership has not yet acknowledged the 'iron triangle' of Speed, Cost, and Quality; they do not seem to understand they only get to pick two. Employees are often jaded or frightened. Layoffs of what are believed to be overpaid employees  in the western US are ongoing, but positions remain open for months in the mid West and Eastern states.

headline: Bankcard Management SUCKS

headline: AMOS Pune Review
pros: Big Brand name, Office parties, Outings
cons:
1. No scope for learning in terms of new technologies. Working on outdated technologies. 
2. Bunch of idiot mangers who doesn't even know how to prepare excel sheets. They even don't know how to talk to your subordinates. 
3. Developers who do the actual work are treated like stray animals and they have to bear most of the pressure.
4. Working on weekends, 15-16 hrs working , No work life balance , No comp offs. One can see everything happening here.
5. Senior exp. professionals are leaving which is making the new joiners a problem to learn technologies.
6. Favoritism is on peek and one can see its effect during appraisal. Office politics, Boot lickering everything is happening here.
7. Lot of fights can be seen happening in between tester, developers and business people on requirements.
8. No proper policies . No standard.
9. Management is least bothered about all this things they are only concerned about achieving target at less cost which is resulting in cutting people.
10 Pathetic work culture.

headline: Worst company ever experienced (Allianz Worldwide Partners)
pros: Decent salary. Some people are actually nice. That's all.
cons:
From management to HR, it's a sport to say one thing and do the other. Unbelievably unprofessional environment across the board, driven by people who just care to keep the status quo and fill their pockets in the meantime. Many highly incompetent people are put in leading positions, and have absolutely no clue on the actual business and topics they're dealing with, nor actual skills to healthily grow teams and the people in them.

Time is relative and appointments are often not respected (and this is supposed to be Germany). IT infrastructure and support are simply a joke. HR systematically plays slimy tricks trying not to fulfil their obligations. 

I can go on with hundreds more bad things... really, stay away from these guys. Don't get initially fooled by cash and big smiles, as it will quickly backfire on your career and health.

headline: It is a trap. Careers get runied here.
pros: NO PROS worth mentioning for this company.
cons:
1. Do not risk your career as you will not be working for Allianz but for AMOS which is a child company of Allianz group and is being totally run by a bunch of Indian "lunatic" management people.

2. Management of this company has found their way in through trickery. They all from Sales and Operations background. They do not know have idea about how to run and manage an IT project. 

3. Employees are treated so badly that many of them had to abscond in order to protect their dignity and self esteem.

4. There are two groups here. One from Barclays operation and not IT and another from Bajaj sales. They constantly do politics amongst themselves to get the upper hand and hard working employees who want to work peacefully always suffer because of this cross fire.

5. Technologies being used such as Eclipse RCP, SOAP web services are obsolete in market. No market recognized framework is being used here. So no career boost in terms of technical knowledge of skills.

6. The management people literally treat employees as casual labour. They do not respect employees or any of your efforts put forth towards the project you work in.

7. Politics and favoritism are the buzz words in this company.

8. Right from the directors, associate directors, and senior managers are recruited through mutual channels in other words perfect juggad and not on merit basis.

9. Appraisals and performance evaluation processes are highly biased and always swing in the direction of favorites of the management.

10. There is only one product which being run in different projects for different countries.

11. There are no events where you can come along with your families.

12. Work life balance is not values here at all.

headline: Micro-Management - Just Bonkers
pros: The pay was OK and I was warned that I might not like the job before I started, so they were honest about it up front. Nice location of the building - it's next to a gym and darling harbor, so after all of your steps done in the morning, you can have a great sanity break.
cons: I felt like I was in a maze of micromanagement. The staff are all required to 6-sigma their entire daily jobs into little tasks on spreadsheets with timers on it - and I mean that is all day, all week, every month, every year. It's so micromanaged that you don't have time to do anything other than these little steps that are crammed into your day so apparently you will be more efficient. I am NOT a robot, and I don't believe that making staff perform steps for their jobs allows anything other than stupidity. IE: NOTHING was automated. There were about a million of these bonker little steps you had to go through, every day and what a lot of trouble you would get into if you forgot a little bonker step. To give you the extent of their micromanagement: I remember aligning some tags on documents that weren't quite straight and having one of the managers in there rip them off because they weren't straight - the tags had to be perfectly aligned and in colour sequence (no business purpose other than to look pretty - don't worry about staff time spent and wages getting a ruler to align the little stickers on the pages so so). As I said, it was just bonkers. How can this company possibly promote creativity in such a regimented environment? Completely Micromanaged to point of complete lunacy. If you like to be controlled for every breath you take, go there. But if you are like me, you will run a mile. I went to another company and implemented a system with workflow to automate every single manual bonker step so I would NEVER have to do anything so nutty again. Funny hey but sad and true.

headline: Pricing Analyst
pros: It's a big international company, and it knows it - makes good use of knowledge/experience sharing among all of its international OE's, which makes the internal support quite strong. For employees it's also very interesting to often get chances to visit other OE's and learn from each other. Also work/life balance is quite good, a lot of freedom to plan your own hours.
cons: Allianz puts in a lot of effort to get the right people, but really neglect the good employees it already has in place, mainly in the sense of salary. And in the process of selecting the right candidates, Allianz tends to skip capability testing and believing all that's in the CV. This resulted in us working with sometimes completely incapable people, who get a 50% higher pay just because they came in through headhunters. Ridiculous.

headline: A Company in early stages, work for 2-3 years and escape.
pros: I have been working in this company for 4 years now. I know how this company works from my 4 years of tenure because the management structure is not very long. It starts with an engineer under me --> me, the lead --> My manager --> Divisional Head --> CEO. This is a shared services company of Allianz. Allianz is not yet confident enough to give all of it's projects to AMOS. So, less projects. Most of the projects are 'operations' kind of tasks, either L1 or L2 or both. Only few projects with L3 support involved. An example is - there is an application and a tool is monitoring it. Now, the operations team monitors this tool :. Very less workload in my opinion. Best company to work for if you are just married. No head aches related to work and you can dedicate all your time for family. One thing I like is there is a fixed/clear appraisal processes (No room for high expectations :P ), Flexible timings - No one cares when you come and leave but work should be completed in SLA. Flexible team members and work style allows telecommuting for short term. Employees are very friendly and their culture is very good. Its always fun in here.
cons: Company structure is not good. No good middle/low level management. All tasks come eventually to a software engineer - be it an project analysis/evaluation, a board/customer presentation. The load is on the shoulders of the last employee. Company has many ambitions but poor planning/execution.. My verdict : A company to work for short term.

headline: Bad management
pros:
Good Work-Life balance. 
Relaxed when doing poor design and architecture for 3 years (pro) and pushing hard developers to finish in 3 months (you decide here)
cons: Management is not interested is their employees. More interested in politics and keeping their chair. Lack of IT vision. The Interesting stuff in IT is outsourced on the ground that internal developers don't have experience...never thought about talking to developers, train them or keeping them. In less than 2 years more than 4-5 team leaders in IT had resigned from my team one after another. Nobody cared why this was happening.

headline: Views of an expat working in the Munich HQ
pros: The scope of the group is very broad and there are very bright, conceptually driven strong colleagues to work with in Munich and very practical, commercial people to work with in the various operating companies around the world. Connecting the two takes energy, however! Having said that, the strength of the group is in its operating entities (OE's in Allianz speak) and there is enough autonomy for them to do the right thing.
cons: The overlapping responsibilities in Munich are a recipe for paralysis, especially when allied to the toxic gossip culture reinforced by 3-5 day a week 1-1 scheduled lunch meetings and a very very German hierarchical style. Another issue is that people are seldom fired but can get shoved from project to project - many seem to view it as a comfortable landing point and are happy to wait their time out. This contributes to a civil service culture that is change averse. It also means that many of the people are massively over-qualified for what they are actually doing day to day - more reasons for creating mischief and the "sweet smell of unnecessary work".

headline: A good starting point for your career in insurance
pros:
- Excellent training. In my department we had a 3 week induction and then further ongoing training. When changes were rolled out across the business we all received thorough training. This often involves sitting exams. I know the exams are off-putting for some people, but I found it helpful to ensure I understood things.
- Opportunities to apply for internal transfers. You need to actively pursue these.
- Flexible leave arrangements. They will let you take leave without pay if you want.
cons:
- There was blatant favouritism in my department. You basically had to be friends with your immediate manager to get anywhere on the career ladder.
- Pay is below industry averages and annual pay increases are often below inflation.
- They have won all sorts of employer of choice for women awards, yet provide very few part time opportunities in my department. Part time staff are often overlooked for career advancement opportunities.
- The annual culture survey always seems to indicate the vast majority of staff are happy. This is not my experience on the floor.
- There is a lot of chopping and changing. I was in 6 different teams in 2.5 years. While I'm not adverse to some degree of change this is pushing it a bit.
- Staff who lodge Workers' Compensation claims are treated terribly. I've seen several cases of people being pushed out the door a few weeks after their claim was wrapped up.

headline: Work-life balance, good employee benefits and innovative on system and technology
pros: Good work-life balance, very friendly colleagues, inovative on technologies and strategies
cons: well below market pay, career developments are limited if you're not in the sales area. Middle-level management can be frustrating as the communication channel breaks down from upper level to grounds. Does not present leadership or live up the company values

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros: Have worked for Allianz for 7 years and cannot speak highly enough of the company. For me it's more than a job, it's somewhere I feel valued and actively enjoy spending time. First and foremost Allianz cares about its people; there are incomparable training and development opportunities for staff and in 7 years I have never once been denied a training request. Wellbeing is a key topic and Allianz allows employees 10 hours paid leave per year to undertake a volunteering activity of their choice. The benefits are excellent; from discounted insurance policies to discounted gym membership, a dry cleaning service on site and numerous other facilities. There is an active Sports and Social club and a robust Reward and Recognition scheme. The culture at Allianz is extremely friendly and many staff have either worked here for years or left and returned to the company - a strong indictment of what a great company it is to work for. The Graduate Schemes are well organised and allow our graduates unrivalled opportunities in training and qualification. Above all, I enjoy coming to work each day and count myself lucky in this respect.
cons: Not always the fastest paced environment to work in.

headline: Probably the best company to work for in Paris
pros: They offer great compensation, benefits and career opportunities. Not to mentoin that this is one of the hottest insurance company on the market.
cons: The environment is not great. You have to make the trip to La Defense every day and it can be a pain.

headline: Super international place to work

A really important time is dedicated to employees training, an a Company own "university" has been created. 
When a new IT system is implemented, training is provided to every employees who will have to use it. Training is also provided to new people in the Company.

headline: U.S. is the worst division of an, otherwise, great global company.

There are federal lawsuits and other major issues because of his treatment. The best decision I made was leaving. The turnover/fire rate the previous poster indicated is accurate. If you like being treated like garbage, take a job there. If you value professionalism, run as fast as possible in any other direction.

headline: Toxic Environment
pros: Subsidiary of well capitalized global insurance company with excellent employee benefits such as health insurance and 401k (100% match up to 7.5%).
cons: New York office is a mess.  Senior leadership in United States has created a toxic environment with poor treatment of employees and unethical behavior.  Employee turnover is a problem (fired or resigned) over the past 3 years (close to 100% turnover).  Two lawsuits have been filed against the company by former US employees in the last 12 months (only 14 employees in NY office).  European headquarters is aware but ignoring the problem.

headline: A Firm With Low & No Growth
pros: Initially, this firm was booming and growing back in 2008. In fact, this firm was doing very well while the rest of Wall Street was crumpling. Overall, the vacation days are decent, good health benefits, fairly young crowd. Work hours stick to a 9-5 parameter.
cons: Very unstable, no growth or opportunity for most workers. Management don't know how to manage, there is very low or no moral. HR is almost do not exsist. There is no cohesiveness or integregration, each department is in its own world. The RIS group is ran like a muck, they do their own things, have their own cake & coffee hours.

headline: Brilliant experience. Good firm to work for a fresher in Trivandrum.
pros: The money was good. Decent salary plus very good variable pay which is up to you to make. Realistic targets which could be achieved with a reasonable effort. A fun place to work with.
cons: I felt that the growth cycle from a CSA level1 to the Assistant Manager post is very long.

headline: Pleasant & challenging experience overall. Focuses on reviewing medical histories & entitlements
pros:
- comprehensive induction program
- autonomy in work
- diversity of tasks
- big company, big opportunities if you play the game
cons:
- work place politics frustrating & sometimes disheartening if you're sensitive
- management do not listen to employee recommendations for system improvements
- policies are changing all the time, hard to keep up and very stressful. If you want to keep on top of your work load and get good sales results for your team, be prepared to work long and hard. 
- high turnover of staff (for case managers that you are leading)
- big focus on reducing costs (i.e. kicking people off the system, which may or may not be possible or recommended)

headline: Working at Allianz is a challenging and satisfying experience with the downsides of a multinational company.
pros: Good remuneration, nice work atmosphere, many opportunities for young and flexible professionals. Challenging projects from day one. Lots of responsibilities even on lower management levels. Flat hierachys
cons: Lack of innovation. Horrible HR department (which is normaly bypassed by line management, so they don't do too much harm)

headline: Well worth it.

- Supportive team and managers

cons: - Lack of existing standard for promotion upon qualifying profession exams

headline: Dysfunctional. CS employees are given unrealistic goals and are penalized and fired when they don't reach those goals.
pros: Decent salary and two fairly decent restaurants on site even if your break time doesn't allow you to visit them before they close for the day.
cons: CS employees routinely thrown under the bus by management when a caller doesn't get their way even though as a CS you've been explicitly told x is not allowed. However, if the customer complains loudly enough their bad behavior is rewarded and the employee becomes the fall guy. In addition, the technology they employ is decades behind the rest of the world and frequently fails or provides incorrect information with cumbersome work-arounds. There is little to no vacation time offered other than a small handful of days for an entire department for an entire year. But aside from all that, probably the worst aspect is the unrealistic call handle times imposed - as a CS employee you're assisting customers with complicated financial packages, often times the customer's life savings and/or retirement funds, but you're limited to only 5.25 minutes per call. If you do not meet this limit you're either placed on a firing warning for exceeding the limit and eventually fired for it or you choose deliver poor customer service to keep your calls as short as possible. If you see a problem with the customer's account and they don't bring it up, you sure aren't going to because that would make the call longer so you leave it be and the customer gets screwed. It would seem the mentality is that Allianz already has the customer's money so why do they care that their CS employees are giving poor CS? It seems that they're only concerned with processing as many calls as possible, it's quantity over quality. Even good employees that have been with the company for years must fear for their jobs every day and even though the company states they promote hiring from within, in the call center it's all smoke and mirrors. It's been years since an employee escaped the call center by getting another job within the company. For most the only exit is with their personal belongings in hand, escorted out the door by security. But there are always more warm bodies desperate for a job, isn't that right?

headline: Quirky company but overall a satisfying experience
pros:
-Interesting clients
-Talented / highly educated employees 
-Training/Development is frequently offered
-Great benefits package 
-High performance is recognized
cons:
-Employee diversity not recognized or celebrated
-Employee morale is generally low 
-Brand awareness continues to be low in the U.S. despite Allianz being among the Fortune 50 global companies
-Change is constant and reasons "why" are rarely communicated
-Annual bonus calculation is a smoke & mirrors game
-Uninspiring Senior Management
